sections.name: Section B: Reading Comprehension - Literary Text

questions.prompt:
Read the passage carefully and answer the questions that follow.

**THE OLD LIGHTHOUSE**

The lighthouse had stood on the cliff for over a hundred years, a silent sentinel guarding the rocky coastline. Its white walls, once pristine, were now weathered and stained by decades of salt spray and storms. Yet to young Emma, it was the most beautiful building in the world.

Every summer, Emma would visit her grandfather, the lighthouse keeper, spending long days exploring the rugged shore and listening to his tales of the sea. Grandfather would tell her about the ships he had guided safely through treacherous waters, the fierce storms he had weathered, and the quiet nights when the ocean lay as still as glass beneath a canopy of stars.

"A lighthouse keeper's job is simple," Grandfather would say, his weathered hands wrapped around a cup of hot tea. "We keep the light burning. No matter what happens, the light must never go out. Sailors depend on it to find their way home."

This summer was different. When Emma arrived, she noticed that Grandfather moved more slowly, his once-strong shoulders now slightly stooped. The stairs to the lamp room, which he used to climb with ease, now left him breathless. Yet his eyes still sparkled when he spoke of his beloved lighthouse.

One stormy night, the power failed. Emma watched as Grandfather struggled to his feet, determination etched on his face. "The light," he whispered urgently. "We must keep the light burning."

Together, they climbed the spiral staircase, Grandfather leaning heavily on Emma's shoulder. With trembling hands, he showed her how to light the backup oil lamp, how to adjust the lens so that its beam would reach far out to sea. As the golden light pierced through the darkness, Grandfather smiled, and Emma understood. Some duties transcend age and weakness. Some lights must never be allowed to go out.

Years later, when Emma became the lighthouse's new keeper, she would often think of that night and her grandfather's unwavering dedication. The lighthouse still stands, its beam sweeping across the dark waters, a symbol of hope and guidance for all who sail past.

questions.prompt:
Your school is organizing an Environment Week to raise awareness about environmental issues.

As the Environment Club President, write an announcement to be read during morning assembly.

Your announcement should include:
• The purpose of Environment Week
• The dates and key activities planned
• How students can participate
• Why students should get involved

Write your announcement in about 150-200 words. Use an appropriate tone for a school announcement.

Write a composition of about 250-300 words on ONE of the following topics.

Topic A: Describe a place that is special to you and explain why it is meaningful.

Topic B: Write about a person who has influenced you greatly.

Topic C: Reflect on an event that changed the way you see the world.

Your composition should:
• Use vivid descriptive language
• Include sensory details (sight, sound, smell, touch, taste)
• Explain the significance or meaning clearly
• Engage the reader with your personal voice

answers.answer: It suggests the lighthouse stands watch over the coastline like a guard or protector, silently keeping ships safe without making a sound.
He told stories about ships he guided safely through dangerous waters, fierce storms he survived, and quiet peaceful nights at sea.
1) He moved more slowly. 2) His shoulders were slightly stooped. 3) Climbing the stairs left him breathless.

It means the lighthouse must always remain lit because sailors depend on it for navigation and to find their way home safely. Metaphorically, it also means some responsibilities must never be abandoned.

Emma helped her grandfather climb the spiral staircase by letting him lean on her shoulder. Together they reached the lamp room, where Grandfather showed her how to light the backup oil lamp and adjust the lens.
She learned that some duties are more important than personal difficulties, and that dedication to one's responsibilities transcends age and physical weakness.

Emma shares a close bond with her grandfather, spending summers listening to his sea tales and helping at the lighthouse. The lighthouse symbolizes duty, dedication, and guidance. When Grandfather passes on his knowledge during a storm, Emma learns that some responsibilities must never be abandoned, inspiring her to become the next keeper.
